Edghill. Analytica priora / by A.J. Jenkinson. Analytica posteriora / by G.R.G. Mure. Oxford : Clarendon Press, 1926. </name> </source> <model> ......... </model> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <work> ......... </work> <source> <IRI>http://id.lib.harvard.edu/aleph/007901738/catalog</IRI> <name>Aristotle: Categoriae & De interpretatione by E.M. Edghill. Analytica priora / by A.J. Jenkinson. Analytica posteriora / by G.R.G. Mure. Oxford : Clarendon Press, 1926. </name> </source> <redivision> ......... </redivision> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <work> ......... </work> <source> <IRI>http://id.lib.harvard.edu/aleph/002773288/catalog</IRI> <name>Logique d'Aristote: Traduite en français pour la première fois et accompagnée de notes perpétuelles par J. Barthélemy Saint-Hilaire. Paris : Ladrange, 1839-1844. </name> </source> <redivision> ......... </redivision> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <work> ......... </work> <source> <IRI>http://id.lib.harvard.edu/aleph/002773288/catalog</IRI> <name>Logique d'Aristote: Traduite en français pour la première fois et accompagnée de notes perpétuelles par J. Barthélemy Saint-Hilaire. Paris : Ladrange, 1839-1844. </name> </source> <redivision> ......... </redivision> ......... </head>

section.para: The element subject points to text references that act as the subject of the claim.
Unlike @subject, which points to any entity via idrefs, <subject> is intended exclusively to point to data content or a textual subject.
Each <subject> is interpreted as a single entity, with all textual references encoded by the element treated as a single, grouped passage.
The element subject specifies expectations on a verb's use of subject. By default, a subject is required.
Takes ID refs that must point to <algorithm>, <organization>, <person>, <work>, <version>, <scriptum>, <topic>, <source>

important.para: No <tok> should duplicate any sibling <tok>.

caution.para: Claims involving verbs whose constrained content requires specification of units must use <object> or <subject> with @units.
<object> or <subject> with @units may be used only with verbs with constrained content.
<subject>s' and <object>s' content must be castable to any datatype constraints defined by the verb.
<subject>s' and <object>s' content must match any lexical constraints defined by the verb.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a:claims"> <head> ......... <vocabulary-key> ......... <verb xml:id="om"> ......... <constraints> <subject status="required" item-type="person work version scriptum"/> <at-ref status="required"/> ......... </constraints> </verb> <verb xml:id="attests"> ......... <constraints> <subject status="required" item-type="person work version scriptum"/> <object status="required" item-type="ref"/> </constraints> </verb> ......... </vocabulary-key> ......... </head> <body claimant="xslt1"> ......... <claim verb="refers-to"> <subject src="grc" ref="1 b 25"/> <object work="grc" ref="1 a 16"/> </claim> </body> </TAN-A>
<claim verb="concerns" object="predication"> <subject src="grc" ref="1 1"/> </claim>

section.para: The element successor identifies a file that succeeds the current file. Successors may or may not have the same @id value.

caution.para: <successor> and <predecessor> must point to TAN files of the same type.
An element that has a <location> and is key for validation should have at least one document available.
Every TAN file referred to by way of an element containing <location> should have an @id that matches the <IRI> of the parent of the <location>
No element may point to a TAN file that has an identical @id value; the only exception is <predecessor> and <successor>.

important.para: If a target file has children items in the <to-do>the corresponding comments will be returned as warnings.
If a target file has a <successor> a warning will be returned, noting the update.
If an element's <location> is faulty and if a catalog file entry is found pointing to a document with the same IRI, location information on those alternative locations will be returned
If a target file points only to non-local locations and no internet is available, the following message will be returned. No internet available.

caution.para: If a linking element points to a file that must be resolved, that file must be a TAN file.

section.para: The element tail permits any arbitrary content. This element is suitable as a placeholder for temporary data, especially to facilitate time-consuming validation routines.
The element TAN-A specifies that the file is a div-based TAN alignment file. Root element.

important.para: Users should be warned about versions of TAN that are under development. This version of TAN is under development, and is subject to change. Participants in developing the TAN schemas, functions, and guidelines are welcome. See http://textalign.net for details.
Users should be warned about TAN files whose last change was made by an algorithm.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a:claims"> <head> ......... </head> <body claimant="xslt1"> ......... </body> </TAN-A>
<TAN-A TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a"> <head> ......... </head> <body claimant="park"> ......... </body> </TAN-A>
<TAN-A TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ring01-TAN-A-ring02"> <head> ......... </head> <body claimant="park"> ......... </body> </TAN-A>

section.para: The element TAN-A-lm specifies that the file is a TAN file containing lexico-morphology data about a text. Root element.

important.para: Users should be warned about versions of TAN that are under development. This version of TAN is under development, and is subject to change. Participants in developing the TAN schemas, functions, and guidelines are welcome. See http://textalign.net for details.
Users should be warned about TAN files whose last change was made by an algorithm.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-lm TAN-version="2020" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs:TAN-A-lm:2016-04-05T07:07:40.033-04:00"> <head> ......... </head> <body lexicon="LSJ Lampe new" morphology="Perseus" claimant="xslt2"> ......... </body> </TAN-A-lm>
<TAN-A-lm TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ring01-lm"> <head> ......... </head> <body lexicon="english" morphology="penn" claimant="xslt2"> ......... </body> </TAN-A-lm>

section.para: The element TAN-A-tok specifies that the file is a token-based TAN alignment file. Root element.

important.para: Users should be warned about versions of TAN that are under development. This version of TAN is under development, and is subject to change. Participants in developing the TAN schemas, functions, and guidelines are welcome. See http://textalign.net for details.
Users should be warned about TAN files whose last change was made by an algorithm.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <head> ......... </head> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation"> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03"> <head> ......... </head> <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear" claimant="xslt2"> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03:alt"> <head> ......... </head> <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear" claimant="xslt2"> ......... </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The element TAN-mor specifies that the TAN file contains codes and rules for the parts of speech for a language, the codes for those parts, and the rules for combining them. Root element.

important.para: Users should be warned about versions of TAN that are under development. This version of TAN is under development, and is subject to change. Participants in developing the TAN schemas, functions, and guidelines are welcome. See http://textalign.net for details.
Users should be warned about TAN files whose last change was made by an algorithm.

example.programlisting: <TAN-mor TAN-version="2020" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-r-mor:eng:penn"> <head> ......... </head> <body> ......... </body> </TAN-mor>

section.para: The element TAN-T specifies that the TAN file contains a transcription. Root element.

important.para: Users should be warned about versions of TAN that are under development. This version of TAN is under development, and is subject to change. Participants in developing the TAN schemas, functions, and guidelines are welcome. See http://textalign.net for details.
Users should be warned about TAN files whose last change was made by an algorithm.

example.programlisting: <TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.eng.1926.edghill:semantic-refs" TAN-version="2020"> <head> ......... </head> <body xml:lang="eng"> ......... </body> </TAN-T>
<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.eng.1926.edghill:model-object-refs" TAN-version="2020"> <head> ......... </head> <body xml:lang="eng"> ......... </body> </TAN-T>
<TAN-T TAN-version="2020" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.fra.1844.saint-hilaire:semantic-refs-realigned"> <head> ......... </head> <body xml:lang="fra"> ......... </body> </TAN-T>
<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.fra.1844.saint-hilaire:semantic-refs" TAN-version="2020"> <head> ......... </head> <body xml:lang="fra"> ......... </body> </TAN-T>

section.para: The element TAN-voc specifies that the TAN file contains vocabulary—things given IRIs + names + descriptions, or token definitions. Root element.

important.para: Users should be warned about versions of TAN that are under development. This version of TAN is under development, and is subject to change. Participants in developing the TAN schemas, functions, and guidelines are welcome. See http://textalign.net for details.
Users should be warned about TAN files whose last change was made by an algorithm.

caution.para: The vocabulary of a file may not include it.

example.programlisting: <TAN-voc TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-key:ar.cat"> <head> ......... </head> <body affects-element="work"> ......... </body> </TAN-voc>
<TAN-voc TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-voc:standard"> <head> ......... </head> <body> ......... </body> </TAN-voc>
<TAN-voc TAN-version="2020" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-voc:bitext-relation"> <head> ......... </head> <body affects-element="bitext-relation"> ......... </body> </TAN-voc>
<TAN-voc TAN-version="2020" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-voc:div-types"> <head> ......... </head> <body affects-element="div-type"> ......... </body> </TAN-voc>

section.para: The element through-tok points to a single token that is the end of a range of tokens to be selected
The element through-tok points to a single token that is the end of a range of tokens to be selected

caution.para: Every token must be locatable in every cited ref in every source.
In a <reassign>, the token referred to at <from-tok> must precede the one referred to by <through-tok>.

example.programlisting: <subject src="eng-uk"> ......... <from-tok ref="1" pos="3"/> <through-tok ref="2" pos="1"/> </subject>

section.para: The element to indicates a ref to which the preceding <tok>s should be moved.

caution.para: No adjustment action should result in the mixing of leaf <div>s and non-leaf <div>s.

section.para: The element to-do lists tasks that remain to be done (via <comment> children). Lack of content in <to-do> suggests that the file is no longer considered a work in progress,

caution.para: Any TAN file without a to-do list will be treated as being no longer in progress and should have at least one master-location.

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <change who="xslt2" when="2018-08-04T23:55:36.096-04:00">Converted from 2018 to 2019 schemas.</change> <to-do/> </head>
<head> ......... <change when="2018-07-30-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">updated to 2019 schemas</change> <to-do/> </head>
<head> ......... <change who="xslt2" when="2018-08-05T00:03:20.142-04:00">Converted from 2018 to 2019 schemas.</change> <to-do/> </head>
<head> ......... <change who="xslt2" when="2018-08-05T00:05:17.879-04:00">Converted from 2018 to 2019 schemas.</change> <to-do/> </head>

section.para: The element tok points to a token in the abstract, no matter where it is found, either in the source (if there is one) or the language (if there is no source).
This version of <tok> does not allow regular expressions (@rgx).
The element tok points to one or more tokens in a source + ref defined by the parent.
The element tok points to one or more tokens in a source defined by the parent.
The element tok identifies one or more words or word fragments. Used by class 2 files to make assertions about specific words.
In TAN-A and TAN-A-tok files, <tok> has no linguistic connotations; in TAN-A-lm, it normally does.

<tok>s that are restricted to a single token, or a portion of a single token. This is the normal behavior of <tok>. Multiple values in @src, @ref, and @pos will result in expansion across all values. But multiple values of @chars are taken to refer to the constituent parts of a single <tok> and so no expansion occurs on @chars.

This syntax allows multiple <tok>s to be collapsed into a single one, to save space and perhaps enhance legibility. For example, a <tok> with 2 values for @src, 3 for @ref, 4 for @pos, and 5 for @chars will result in a <tok> that points to 24 tokens, each of which is filtered to the same five characters (by position, not content). Put another way, <tok src="X" ref="a" pos="1"/> and <tok src="X" ref="a" pos="2"/> is always identical to <tok src="X" ref="a" pos="1-2"/>
If you wish to treat multiple word fragments as a single token, use <group>.

caution.para: Every token must be locatable in every cited ref in every source.
Every character must be locatable in every token in every ref in every source.

important.para: No <tok> should duplicate any sibling <tok>.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ar.cat.tan-a:claims"> ......... <body claimant="xslt1"> ......... <claim subject="andronicus boethus" adverb="perhaps" verb="om" xml:id="cl1a2a"> <at-ref src="grc" ref="1 a 2"> <tok pos="3-4"/> </at-ref> </claim> ......... <claim subject="comm-omnes" verb="attests"> <object src="grc" ref="1 a 2"> <tok pos="3-4"/> </object> </claim> <claim subject="comm-omnes" verb="attests" xml:id="cl1a2b"> <object src="grc" ref="1 a 2"> <tok pos="3-4"/> </object> </claim> ......... <claim subject="B" verb="reads"> <at-ref src="grc" ref="1 a 5"> <tok pos="1-2"/> </at-ref> ......... </claim> <claim subject="Λ" adverb="perhaps" verb="reads"> <at-ref src="grc" ref="1 a 5"> <tok pos="1-2"/> </at-ref> ......... </claim> <claim subject="π α φ ο" verb="matches"> <object src="grc" ref="1 a 5"> <tok pos="1-2"/> </object> </claim> ......... </body> </TAN-A>

section.para: The element tok-is specifies the exact values of every @val of <tok>s in the file.
The element tok-starts-with specifies an opening string that characterizes the @val of <tok>s in the file.
The element token-definition takes a regular expression to define a word token. This element will be used to segment a string into token and non-token components.
This element takes attributes that function as the parameters for the function xsl:analyze-string (see https://www.w3.org/TR/xslt-30/#element-analyze-string).

caution.para: No source may be given more than one token definition.

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <license which="by_4.0" licensor="park"/> <token-definition src="eng-us" pattern="[-\w]+"/> <source xml:id="eng-uk"> ......... </source> ......... </head>
<head> ......... <license licensor="kalvesmaki"> ......... </license> <token-definition pattern="[\w­​‍]+"/> <inclusion xml:id="rel"> ......... </inclusion> ......... </head>
<head> ......... <license licensor="park"> ......... </license> <token-definition which="letters and punctuation"/> <source> ......... </source> ......... </head>
<head> ......... <license licensor="park"> ......... </license> <token-definition src="ring1881 ring1987" which="letters"/> <source xml:id="ring1881"> ......... </source> ......... </head>

section.para: The element topic declares one or more topics, to be used in conjunction with @topic under <align> to associate alignments with specific topics instead of verbatim parallels.
Takes ID refs that must point to <topic>

example.programlisting: <vocabulary-key> ......... <verb which="is about" xml:id="concerns"/> <topic xml:id="predication"> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:topic:predication</IRI> <name>predication</name> <desc>The act of asserting something about a grammatical subject.</desc> </topic> </vocabulary-key>

section.para: The element unit contains an IRI + name pattern identifying a unit type (e.g., millimeters, seconds, Euros), to be used in conjunction with <object> to specify the meaning of a value
The element value states the value of a <checksum>

example.programlisting: <checksum> ......... <name>SHA-1</name> <value>91D95564ABDF2B2C1B9EEF016CBA51E8179646CC</value> </checksum>

section.para: The element verb contains an IRI + name pattern identifying a property, relationship, action, or something else that is used to say something about something.
The preferred term "verb" is equivalent to RDF "predicate." The latter term is avoided as misleading, since in ordinary usage the term "predicate" designates both the verb and everything it governs.
Takes ID refs that must point to <verb>

caution.para: Claims involving verbs whose constrained content requires specification of units must use <object> or <subject> with @units.
<object> or <subject> with @units may be used only with verbs with constrained content.
A claim with a verb that has content constraints must not allow other verbs.

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <vocabulary-key> ......... <alias xml:id="comm-omnes" idrefs="π δ α.d φ.d ο.d η.d σ.d"/> <verb which="refers or alludes to" xml:id="refers-to"/> <verb xml:id="om"> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:verb:omits</IRI> <name>omits</name> <name>omits text</name> ......... </verb> <verb xml:id="attests"> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:verb:attests-to</IRI> <name>attests</name> <name>attests to</name> ......... </verb> <modal which="possibly" xml:id="perhaps"/> ......... </vocabulary-key> ......... </head>
<vocabulary-key> ......... <role xml:id="stylesheet1" which="stylesheet"/> <verb which="is about" xml:id="concerns"/> <topic xml:id="predication"> ......... </topic> </vocabulary-key>

section.para: The element version identifies the version of a work. Applicable to sources that contain multiple versions, e.g., original text and facing translations. Like <work>, <version> points to a conceptual entity, not a physical one.

In the context of a class 1 file, the entity identified by <version> is assumed to be a version of the entity defined in <work>. In TAN-c files, however, no relationship is assumed between <version> and any putative work, unless explicitly stated in that file.

Very few work-versions have their own URN names. It is advisable to assign a tag URN or a UUID. If you have used an IRI for <work> that you are entitled to modify, you may wish to add a suffix that will name the version. If you need to specify exactly where on a text-bearing object a version appears, <desc> or <comment> should be used.

The element version identifies the version of a work. Applicable to sources that contain multiple versions, e.g., original text and facing translations. Like <work>, <version> points to a conceptual entity, not a physical one.

In the context of a class 1 file, the entity identified by <version> is assumed to be a version of the entity defined in <work>. In TAN-c files, however, no relationship is assumed between <version> and any putative work, unless explicitly stated in that file.

Very few work-versions have their own URN names. It is advisable to assign a tag URN or a UUID. If you have used an IRI for <work> that you are entitled to modify, you may wish to add a suffix that will name the version. If you need to specify exactly where on a text-bearing object a version appears, <desc> or <comment> should be used.
Takes ID refs that must point to <version>

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <work> ......... </work> <version> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:version:matthews-version-of-the-lords-prayer</IRI> <name>Matthew's version of the Lord's Prayer</name> </version> <vocabulary> ......... </vocabulary> ......... </head>
<head> ......... <work> ......... </work> <version> <IRI>urn:uuid:31648039-3dbb-49b9-b66e-9bd2cd11630e</IRI> <name>zweite Version</name> </version> <numerals priority="letters"/> ......... </head>

section.para: The element vocabulary specifies a TAN-voc file that defines concepts that may be invoked by @which.

caution.para: No file may import vocabularies with items that have duplicate IRIs.
<vocabulary> must point to TAN-voc files.
Inclusions/vocabularies may not be invoked circularly.
The vocabulary of a file may not include it.

important.para: The @TAN-version for inclusions and vocabularies should match the current version.

caution.para: An element that has a <location> and is key for validation should have at least one document available.
Every TAN file referred to by way of an element containing <location> should have an @id that matches the <IRI> of the parent of the <location>
No element may point to a TAN file that has an identical @id value; the only exception is <predecessor> and <successor>.

important.para: If a target file has children items in the <to-do>the corresponding comments will be returned as warnings.
If a target file has a <successor> a warning will be returned, noting the update.
If an element's <location> is faulty and if a catalog file entry is found pointing to a document with the same IRI, location information on those alternative locations will be returned
If a target file points only to non-local locations and no internet is available, the following message will be returned. No internet available.

caution.para: If a linking element points to a file that must be resolved, that file must be a TAN file.

important.para: If @accessed-when predates one or more dates in a target file, a warning will be returned.

caution.para: An element's @which must have a value that corresponds to a <name>, either in a standard TAN vocabulary or an associated TAN-voc file, that is marked as applying to that element.
A @which in a <vocabulary> may point only to items in the standard TAN file vocabularies.TAN-voc.xml
Vocabularies are integral parts of a document. Access to at least one version is absolutely mandatory.

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <version> ......... </version> <vocabulary> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-voc:standard</IRI> <name>Keywords for TAN files edited by Jenny Park</name> <location href="TAN-voc/park-projects.TAN-voc.xml" accessed-when="2019-10-08"/> </vocabulary> <source which="kjv 1760"/> ......... </head>

<TAN-T TAN-version="2020" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:bible:matthew"> <head> ......... <inclusion xml:id="serm-mount"> ......... </inclusion> <vocabulary which="bible eng" accessed-when="2019-10-08"/> <vocabulary> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-voc:standard</IRI> <name>Keywords for TAN files edited by Jenny Park</name> <location href="TAN-voc/park-projects.TAN-voc.xml" accessed-when="2019-10-08"/> </vocabulary> <source which="kjv 1760"/> ......... </head> ......... </TAN-T>

<head> ......... <source> ......... </source> <vocabulary> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-voc:standard</IRI> <name>Vocabulary for TAN files edited by Jenny Park</name> <location href="TAN-voc/park-projects.TAN-voc.xml" accessed-when="2020-01-10"/> </vocabulary> <model> ......... </model> ......... </head>

section.para: The element vocabulary-key contains vocabulary defined for the immediate file.
section.synopsis:
~ed-stamp?, (<comment>* & ( (<person> | <organization> | <algorithm>)* & <role>* & <period>* & <alias>* & <relationship>*) & {[TAN-class-1 (~voc-key-non-core):] (<div-type>* & {empty})} OR
{[TAN-class-2 (~voc-key-non-core):] (<group-type>* & {{[TAN-A-lm (~voc-element-non-class-2):] (<lexicon>+ & <morphology>+)}} OR
{{[TAN-A-tok (~voc-element-non-class-2):] (<bitext-relation>+ & <reuse-type>+)}} OR
{{[TAN-A (~voc-element-non-class-2):] (<work>* & <place>* & <unit>* & <div-type>* & <modal>* & <version>* & <scriptum>* & <topic>* & <verb>*)}} OR
{{[TAN-class-2 (~voc-element-non-class-2):] {empty}}})} OR
{[TAN-class-3 (~voc-key-non-core):] (<group-type>* & {{[TAN-mor (~voc-element-non-class-3):] <feature>*}} OR
{{[TAN-class-3 (~voc-element-non-class-3):] {empty}}})} OR
{[TAN-core (~voc-key-non-core):] {empty}})

section.para: The element where identifies a condition that permits the following adjustment actions to be performed.
The condition must be true for each attribute, for at least one value in that attribute.
Takes ID refs that must point to <place>
The element work identifies a creative textual work, understood conceptually, not physically (e.g., Homer's Iliad, not a particular version or copy of it).

The term "work" is only loosely defined in TAN. Any text that has enough unity to be referred to in ordinary conversation as a single entity may be identified as a work. A work may be composed of other works, be a part of other works, or even overlap with other works. E.g., the Lord's Prayer, the Gospel of Luke, the Tetravengelion, the New Testament, and the Bible are all valid works, despite the complex relationship between each of them.
This element takes the IRI + name pattern. For more, see

section.para: TAN-A: Redefining TAN-body-core not only defines what is in the body of a TAN-A but also excludes groups from it.
TAN-core: String that specifies a single <div>
TAN-core: String that specifies a range of divs using the div-ref pattern joined by a hyphen or a comma.
TAN-core: String that specifies a single item from a sequence: digits or "last(-digit)?" Similar to data-picker-sequence.
TAN-core: String that specifies a range of items in a sequence: digits or "last(-digit)?" joined by hyphens (ranges) or commas. Similar to data-picker-item.
TAN-core: Tag URN, mandatory pattern for the IRI name of every TAN file
TAN-core: Editorial stamp: who created or edited the enclosed data and when.

section.synopsis:
( (<inclusion>* & <vocabulary>* & {{[TAN-A-lm (~source-list):] <source>*}} OR
{{[TAN-A-tok (~source-list):] ~source-list}} OR
{{[TAN-A (~source-list):] <source>*}} OR
{{[TAN-voc (~source-list):] {empty}}} OR
{{[TAN-class-3 (~source-list):] <source>*}} OR
{{[TAN-core (~source-list):] <source>}} & <see-also>* & <predecessor>* & <successor>*) & {[TAN-class-1 (~networked-files-non-core):] (<redivision>* & <model>? & <annotation>* & <companion-version>*)} OR
{[TAN-core (~networked-files-non-core):] {empty}})

section.para: Takes ID refs that must point to <algorithm>, <organization>, <person>, <work>, <version>, <scriptum>, <topic>, <source>, <claim>
TAN-A-tok: TAN-A-tok files take exactly two sources
TAN-A: TAN-A files must have zero or more sources
TAN-class-3: Class 3 files allow zero or many sources
Takes ID refs that must point to <algorithm>, <organization>, <person>, <work>, <version>, <scriptum>, <topic>, <source>
